en.purpose: To apply standardized Rome IV criteria for diagnosing NBS, ensuring consistency in clinical decision-making and supporting opioid tapering strategies when appropriate.
en.use:
Patients presenting with chronic abdominal pain and a history of opioid use for ≥3 months.

The clinician checks for the presence of the following Rome IV criteria:

Chronic or worsening abdominal pain related to opioid use.

Pain worsens with continued opioid use.

Pain improves with dose reduction or cessation of opioids.

Other gastrointestinal disorders ruled out.
en.misuse:
Do not use for diagnosing opioid withdrawal syndrome.

Not a substitute for clinical judgment, other medical conditions should be ruled out.

gt0001.text: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Narcotic Bowel Syndrome (NBS)
gt0001.description: A clinical decision support guideline that helps healthcare providers diagnose NBS using Rome IV criteria. The guideline provides a structured approach to assess symptoms, ensuring accurate diagnosis and differentiation from other opioid-related GI conditions.

gt0003.text: Chronic or frequently recurring abdominal pain (occurs most days) that is treated with acute high-dose or chronic narcotics

gt0004.text: The nature and intensity of the pain is not explained by a current or previous Gl diagnosis

gt0005.text: The pain worsens or incompletely resolves with continued or escalating dosages of narcotics

gt0006.text: There is marked worsening of pain when the narcotic dose wanes and improvement when narcotics are re-instituted (soar and crash)

gt0007.text: There is a progression of the frequency, duration, and intensity of pain episodes
